comment.body: Python can't find the shared library, even though I think it's pointing to the right file. Any ideas, @vsoftco or @xvzcf?
I think I've figued it out. Will update tomorrow.

issue.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
issue.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are: (Updated)

1. ~~Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)~~
[Update] I have found out that DllImport actually prepend "lib" into library names for linux and macOS. However, they have to be exact as in "liboqs.so" is not equals to "liboqs.so.0.0.0" As a result, the changes would just be [DllImport("oqs")] instead. (If you want to support the versioning, AssemblyLoadContext would be needed)

2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)

3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.

4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of Windows, Linux and macOS variants)

5. Updated documentation in README.md to have a slightly more verbose information on how to build the sample application and the wrapper.

Sample Application Tested on:
- [x] Windows 10
- [x] Linux (Ubuntu 18.04 LTS)
- [x] macOS (Mojave)

Relevant issues: #2 #10

comment.body: Cmake is much better :) easier to modify options than using a file.

issue.title: Change to use CMake for liboqs

comment.body: @dstebila @xvzcf This mostly looks good, but allow me to suggest considering an alternative to throwing away the library version ("0.0.0") entirely: Keep it as it was by adding it back in CMake, e.g. like this: `sed -i "s/\# For Windows/VERSION 0.0.0\n\# For Windows/g" src/CMakeLists.txt` (or just rather edit it in to that file :). Of course, if we don't foresee ever changing the APIs, we could make do without (as you do in this PR). If this is what you want, the PR is good, of course. Otherwise we can rewrite the openssl install rules to match whichever way liboqs was build (static or shared or both).

issue.title: Add sanitizer builds
issue.body: A very simple `--with-sanitizer` to enable ASAN and UBSAN. This will produce a couple errors that will need to get fixed before this should be enabled on CI. Note that this should always go along with  `CC=clang`.

issue.title: Add continuous integration test for memory leaks
issue.body:
Possibly using valgrind?

Would have caught #601, #600, #603.

comment.body: #617 adds the option for building with address sanitizer, but currently there are memory leaks, so I haven't enabled the test in CI yet.

issue.title: autoconf configuration leads to hacks for building on ARM
issue.body: When building on ARM (#460), a few hacks had to be introduced in order to work around problems with autoconf.  In particular, see the `hacks` array inside `scripts/arm-cross-compile.sh`.  Each line there is something that should be fixed.

comment.body: Deprecated after move to CMake. For ARM cross compilation see #618

issue.title: Add options for iOS and Android cross-compilation
issue.body: I'm attempting to build liboqs for both iOS and Android for a Xamarin.Forms project, and haven't been able to manipulate the included build and configuration files to make that work. If it would be possible, add configuration or documentation to help with cross-compiling the library for iOS and Android, ideally targeting multiple processor configurations. Thanks!

comment.body: Should be okay to start looking at the iOS and Android cross-compilation again since our change to CMake has landed.  FYI I've started a PR for cross-compilation on Raspberry Pi #618.
